awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Measurement of Copper Speciation in Basaltic Glasses using X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy, a New Window on Metal Solubility and Transport in Magmatic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The solubility of metals such as copper (Cu) in silicate melts can be strongly influenced by natural properties of the magma such as pressure, temperature, and melt composition. Understanding how such things control metal solubility, particularly for Cu, is important for a number of reasons. It helps researchers understand potential driving mechanisms for core formation in terrestrial planets, or the conditions that lead to the formation of economically important metallogenic ore deposits. It's also key to understanding how volcanic degassing may impact metal emissions to the atmosphere. This study proposes to use synchrotron-based X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy of natural and synthetic magmatic glasses with the goal of providing the first direct, experimental constraints on the speciation of Cu in terrestrial melts. XAFS is currently the only methodology available for directly measuring Cu speciation in magmatic glasses at natural concentrations with high spatial resolution. In addition to the scientific goal of constraining which Cu species exist in melts, this work will broaden the participation of minority students in geoscience, and train students in state-of-the-art experimental and analytical techniques.

This will be achieved through three overlapping projects. Project 1 will include copper speciation measurements of synthetic basaltic glasses that are produced at controlled sulfur and oxygen conditions. This suite of synthetic glasses will have both oxygen and sulfur fugacity carefully controlled and will then be analyzed for changes in Cu speciation using XAFS. Project 2 includes Cu speciation measurements of natural glasses sampled from volcanic systems. This project targets natural samples from a sulfide-dominated system with H2O-poor melts (using samples collected from the Kilauea summit vent between 2008 and present), samples from a sulfide-dominated system with higher-H2O melts (from a basaltic cinder cone in the southern Cascade Range), and from sulfate dominated volcanics from both the southern Cascades Range and the Colima Graben in western Mexico. Project 3 will focus on developing advanced, synchrotron-based spectroscopic techniques for Cu K-edge XAFS of magmatic glasses, which will be applied to samples available from Projects 1 and 2, with a focus on developing High Energy-Resolution Fluorescence Detected XAFS (HERFD-XAFS) techniques for the analysis of Cu in geologic materials and magmatic glasses specifically. Such new HERFD-XAFS techniques hold the promise of providing superior spectroscopic sensitivity and resolution compared to conventional XAFS methods for uniquely constraining the copper ligands are present in these samples. These proposed measurements will be the first application of these methods to magmatic glasses and will establish a new database of spectroscopic measurements that will be available to the petrology community. Together, this suite of studies will significantly contribute to our understanding of metal solubility and transport in magmatic systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Copper (Cu) solubility and transport in magmatic fluids is controlled by Cu speciation. Understanding the controls on Cu complexing within magmatic systems, therefore, provides better constraint on the precipitation of Cu-bearing minerals within ore deposits. This study investigated Cu speciation in natural magmatic glasses from reduced and oxidized systems with the main goal of determining how melt composition and oxygen fugacity (fO2) influence Cu speciation in terrestrial melts. Samples from the summit eruption in Kīlauea, Hawaii (2008-2014) represented an H2O-poor, sulfide-dominated volcanic system, while samples from the Lassen Volcanic Center in the southern Cascades Range and the Michoacán–Guanajuato Volcanic Field in western Mexico served as examples of more oxidized sulfate-dominated systems with higher H2O. Copper speciation was collected from melt inclusions (MI) within olivine hosts using X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy.

Within the Kīlauea system, we demonstrated that Cu speciation in MI show a positive correlation between the calculated copper sulfide/copper oxide (Cu(I)-S/Cu(I)-O) complexing ratio and measured S abundance. Kīlauea MI with S abundances > 1000 ppm were observed to have Cu(I)-S species dominant, while S abundances < 500 ppm contain predominantly Cu(I)-O. More detailed studies of Kīlauea MI included high spatial resolution analyses of inclusions that preserve complex inclusion characteristics. This includes MI with vapor bubbles and evidence of post-entrapment crystallization phases. Such spatially-resolved analyses of compositionally heterogeneous MI are aimed at understanding how bubble formation and sulfide crystallization may alter the Cu speciation of the MI glass. Overall, these samples do show increased variability in Cu speciation compared to our earlier set of Kīlauea MI analyses. These results also show that in MI where vapor bubbles are present, no clear correlation is noted with variations in measured Cu speciation. Therefore, it is not yet clear the degree to which sulfide precipitates that can form on bubble walls alter the Cu speciation within the rest of the MI. New data for these MI also include Fe XANES, which help evaluate how variations in Cu speciation may be correlated with changes in Fe valence and melt oxidation. Spatially-resolved S XANES from our summit Kīlauea MI will be collected and used to also better constrain the relationship between copper and sulfur speciation. These S XANES data, along with the Fe XANES collected in this study, are not only useful for an evaluation of Cu complexing, but will be a valuable addition for the wider geochemical community as S and Fe XANES data are lacking for the Kīlauea summit eruption in particular.
